{"id":"ebl-1562718027608-1562718027668-0","version":"","unitCode":"NAA","linkedId":"ebl-1562718027608-1562718027627-0","type":"ead_component","content":{"freetext":{"arrangement":[{"label":"Arrangement","content":"The material is arranged chronologically by document type."}],"setName":[{"label":"See more items in","indexedContent":"MS 4558 Alice Cunningham Fletcher and Francis La Flesche papers","content":"MS 4558 Alice Cunningham Fletcher and Francis La Flesche papers"},{"label":"See more items in","indexedContent":"MS 4558 Alice Cunningham Fletcher and Francis La Flesche papers / Series 3: Papers relating to the anthropological research of Alice Fletcher and Francis La Flesche","content":"MS 4558 Alice Cunningham Fletcher and Francis La Flesche papers / Series 3: Papers relating to the anthropological research of Alice Fletcher and Francis La Flesche"}],"identifier":[{"label":"Identifier","content":"NAA.MS4558, Subseries 3.20"}],"scopecontent":[{"label":"Scope and Contents","content":"Fletcher collected ethnographic information while allotting land to the Nez Perce for the Bureau of Indian Affairs between 1889 and 1892. She never published on the Nez Perce, although she did maintain correspondence with some informants for years after finishing her allotment work.\n\nThis subseries includes items sent to Fletcher by Kate McBeth, a missionary among the Nez Perce who provided Fletcher with much information. For other letters from Kate McBeth, see Fletcher\u0027s incoming correspondence (subseries 1.1).\n\nIn 1926, Francis La Flesche submitted Alice Fletcher\u0027s manuscript on the Nez Perce to J. W. Fewkes for publication by the Bureau of American Ethnology; Fewkes decided against publishing the material (Fewkes to La Flesche, 10-4-26, in La Flesche general correspondence). F. W. Hodge appears to have annotated one of the drafts.\n\nFletcher\u0027s informant, Billy Williams, drew a map titled \"Nez Perce Country,\" which is located in the map case (drawer 1, photo mounted in corner, neg. no. 55,020). The collection also includes four negatives of Williams (BAE neg. nos. 55,021 a, b, c)."}],"unitdate":[{"flag":["era:ce","normal:1889/1909","type:inclusive"],"label":"Date","indexedContent":"1889/1909","content":"1889-1909"}],"userestrict":[{"flag":["inherited"],"label":"Collection Rights","content":"Contact the repository for terms of use."}],"name":[{"flag":["personal_name","personal_main","inherited"],"label":"Collection Creator","indexedContent":"La Flesche, Francis","content":"La Flesche, Francis, 1857-1932"},{"flag":["personal_name","personal_main","inherited"],"label":"Collection Creator","indexedContent":"Fletcher, Alice C. {"id":"ebl-1503512914364-1503512914459-1","version":"","unitCode":"NAA","linkedId":"ebl-1503512914364-1503512914402-0","type":"ead_component","content":{"freetext":{"setName":[{"label":"See more items in","indexedContent":"MS 4800 James O. Dorsey papers"}],"identifier":[{"label":"Identifier","content":"NAA.MS4800, Series 2"}],"sponsor":[{"label":"Sponsor","content":"Creation of this finding aid was funded through support from the Arcadia Fund.\nDigitization and preparation of additional materials for online access has been funded also by the National Science Foundation under BCS Grant No. 1561167 and the Recovering Voices initiative at the Smithsonian\u0027s National Museum of Natural History."}],"scopecontent":[{"label":"Scope and Contents","content":"Dorsey conducted research at Siletz Reservation in Oregon from August to November in 1884. This series contains his field notes from his work with various tribes at the reservation as well as his later analysis of his notes. He collected notes on Applegate Creek, Galice, Chasta Costa, Upper Coquille, Chetco (Tolowa), Mikonotunne (Mackanotin), Tutu, Joshua, Euchre Creek, Sixes, Naltunnetunne, Smith River, Upper Umpqua, Yaquina, Alsea, Siuslaw, Lower Umpqua, Takelma, Sasti (Shasta), and Klikitat. The series consists primarily of vocabulary and notes on grammar, as well as myths, sketch maps, notes on social structure, a list of villages, and a manuscript. There are also letters regarding botanical specimens and plant names that he collected at the reservation."}],"unitdate":[{"flag":["era:ce","normal:1881/1889","type:inclusive"],"label":"Date","indexedContent":"1881/1889","content":"1881 - 1889"},{"flag":["era:ce","type:inclusive"],"label":"Date","indexedContent":"","content":"undated"}],"userestrict":[{"flag":["inherited"],"label":"Collection Rights","content":"Contact the repository for terms of use."}],"name":[{"flag":["personal_name","personal_main","inherited"],"label":"Collection Creator","indexedContent":"Dorsey, James Owen","content":"Dorsey, James Owen, 1848-1895"}],"prefercite":[{"flag":["inherited"],"label":"Collection Citation","content":"Manuscript 4800 James O. {"id":"ebl-1503511520473-1503511520489-0","version":"","unitCode":"NAA","linkedId":"","type":"ead_collection","content":{"freetext":{"setName":[{"label":"See more items in","indexedContent":"Robert Francis Maher papers","content":"Robert Francis Maher papers"}],"identifier":[{"label":"Identifier","content":"NAA.1997-02"}],"sponsor":[{"label":"Sponsor","content":"Funding for the processing of this collection as well as for digitization of the sound recording was provided by the the Arcadia Fund."}],"creator":[{"label":"Creator","content":"Maher, Robert F. (Robert Francis), 1922-1987"}],"bioghist":[{"label":"Biographical Note","content":"Robert F. Maher was born in Eldora, Iowa in 1922. He studied anthropology at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and received his B.S. in 1948, his M.A. in 1950, and his Ph.D. in 1958. He was an instructor at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee in 1953-1954, and at DePauw University in 1956-1957. He joined the Department of Sociology at Western Michigan University in 1957 and became professor of anthropology there in 1966. In 1967, he became the first chairman of the UWM department of Anthropology. He remained at UWM until he died.\n\nMost of Maher\u0027s publications concern his work in Oceania. In 1954-1955, as a Ford Foundation fellow he began research on the Namau, the people of the Purari Delta in Papua New Guinea, concentrating on culture change and, in particular, on the modernist Tommy Kabu Movement. In 1961, he published New Men of Papua: A Study in Cultural Change which earned him the Genevieve Gorst Herfurth Award for outstanding social science. He returned to Papua New Guinea in 1973, 1974, 1976, 1978, 1982, and 1983, often only staying there for a small amount of time.\n\nIn 1960-1961, Maher began a Senior Fulbright Research Grant funded study of the ethnological and archeological history of the Ifugao region of the Philippines. He returned to that area in 1973, 1975, 1978, and 1982. While in Ifugao, Maher conducted cultural studies and excavations in eleven villages and over four agricultural districts including the Banaue, Burnay, and Kiangan districts.\n\nMaher also carried out ethnological and archeological work in the United States. He was a member of the University of Wisconsin Chippewa Reservation Research Project in 1951-1952, and he and his students worked with the Potowatomi of Michigan from 1959 forward. In 1952, he was an assistant director of excavations at the Black Widow site in South Dakota for the River Basin Surveys. He also carried out archeological work in Wisconsin and at Aztalan in the Southwest. Outside the United States, he carried out a survey of villages in Okyama Prefecture in Japan in 1960.\n\nMaher died of cancer in 1987 shortly before he was due to retire after 30 years of teaching. The University of Western Michigan has established an anthropology scholarship in his name.\n\nSources Consulted:\n\nSolheim, Wilhelm G.\n 1967  Robert F. Maher 1922-1987. Asian Perspectives 27(1).\n\nChronology\n\n1922 -- Born on July 14 in Eldora, Iowa\n\n1948 -- B.S. in Anthropology from the University of Wisconson at Madison\n\n1950 -- M.S. in Anthropology from the University of Wisconsin at Madison\n\n1953-1954 -- Instructor at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee\n\n1954-1955 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea\n\n1956-1957 -- Instructor at DePauw University\n\n1958 -- Ph.D. in Anthropology from the University of Wisconsin at Madison\n\n1959-1960 -- Research on the Potawatomi in Michigan\n\n1960 -- Fieldwork in Okayama Prefecture, Japan\n\n1960-1961 -- Fieldwork in the Philippines\n\n1961 -- Published New Men of Papua\n\n1966-1987 -- Professor at Western Michigan University\n\n1973 -- Fieldwork in the Philippines Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea\n\n1974 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea\n\n1975 -- Fieldwork in the Philippines\n\n1976 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea\n\n1978 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea Fieldwork in the Philippines\n\n1982 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea Fieldwork in the Philippines\n\n1983 -- Fieldwork in Papua New Guinea\n\n1987 -- Died of cancer on March 26"}],"processinfo":[{"label":"Processing Information","content":"Processed by Adam Fielding, 2014.\n\nEncoded by Adam Fielding, August 2014."}],"unitdate":[{"flag":["era:ce","normal:1944/1987","type:inclusive"],"label":"Date","indexedContent":"1944/1987","content":"1944-1987"},{"flag":["era:ce","normal:1954/1987","type:bulk"],"label":"Date","indexedContent":"1954/1987","content":"bulk 1954-1987"}],"acqinfo":[{"label":"Provenance","content":"These papers were donated to the National Anthropological Archives by Robert Maher\u0027s wife, Lee Maher, in 1988."}],"physdesc":[{"label":"Extent","content":"7 Sound recordings"},{"label":"Extent","content":"6.38 Linear feet (13 boxes)"}],"abstract":[{"label":"Summary","content":"Robert Francis Maher (1922-1987) was an anthropologist with the University of Western Michigan whose work focused on Oceania. The collection documents his field research in Papua New Guinea and the Philippines. His field research in Papua New Guinea focused on cultural change in the Purari Delta and the modernist Tommy Kabu Movement (1946-1968). His field research in the Philippines focused on the ethnological and archaelogical history and changes in the Ifugao province. The collection consists of field notes, excavation notes, census data, genealogy charts, grant applications, research files, research proposals, maps, correspondence, manuscripts, sound recordings, and photographs."}],"accessrestrict":[{"label":"Restrictions","content":"The Robert Francis Maher papers is open for research. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice."}],"objectType":[{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Collection descriptions","content":"Collection descriptions"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Archival materials","content":"Archival materials"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Sound recordings","content":"Sound recordings"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Photographs","content":"Photographs"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Manuscripts","content":"Manuscripts"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Maps","content":"Maps"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Field notes","content":"Field notes"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Genealogical tables","content":"Genealogical tables"},{"label":"Type","indexedContent":"Correspondence","content":"Correspondence"}],"arrangement":[{"label":"Arrangement","content":"This collection is arranged in 6 series:\n\nSeries 1: Research, 1944, 1954-1985\n\nSeries 2: Correspondence, 1953-1987\n\nSeries 3: Writings, 1961-1983\n\nSeries 4: Writings by Others, circa 1950s - circa 1980s\n\nSeries 5: Sound Recordings, undated\n\nSeries 6: Photographs"}],"scopecontent":[{"label":"Scope and Contents","content":"The papers of Robert F. Maher document his field research in Papua New Guinea and the Philippines. His field research in Papua New Guinea focused on cultural change in the Purari Delta and the modernist Tommy Kabu Movement (1946-1968). His field research in the Philippines focused on the ethnological and archaelogical history and changes in the Ifugao province. The collection consists of field notes, excavation notes, census data, genealogy charts, grant applications, research files, research proposals, maps, correspondence, manuscripts, sound recordings, and photographs.\n\nThe Papua New Guinea research files primarily consist of Maher\u0027s fieldwork diary from 1954-1955. Included with the diary is an annotated partial typescript transcription. Other material includes excavation notes and dwelling information. There is also census material from Tommy Kabu about a work area known as Rabia Camp. The diary describes Maher\u0027s time with Tommy Kabu at Rabia Camp and Port Moresby, as well as his time in the Purari Delta.\n\nThe Philippines research files include field notes, excavation notes, census data, genealogy charts, and research files. The field notes contain detailed reports on pottery, tools, and agricultural and social aspects of the Ifugao province. The census data chiefly contains undated questionnaires filled out by residents of different Ifugao villages. The research files contain reports along with correspondence. Some of the fieldwork reports, along with census data and genealogy charts, were probably authored by two of Maher\u0027s research assistants, Emilio Pagada and Ben Pitpitunge.\n\nThe bulk of the correspondence is professional in nature, and primarily concern his work in the Philippines. Included is correspondence with anthropologists Harold C. Conklin, William A. Longacre, Daniel J. Scheans, Richard Shutler, and Wilheim G. Solheim. Also included are letters from Tommy Kabu.\n\nThe sound recordings contain 5 magnetic tape reels (3 in.) likely recorded in the Ifugao Provice of the Philippines.\n\nThe photographs and slides are unprocessed."}],"genre_format":[{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Photographs","content":"Photographs"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Manuscripts","content":"Manuscripts"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Sound recordings","content":"Sound recordings"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Maps","content":"Maps"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Field notes","content":"Field notes"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Genealogical tables","content":"Genealogical tables"},{"label":"Genre/Form","indexedContent":"Correspondence","content":"Correspondence"}],"bibliography":[{"label":"Selected Bibliography","content":"1958. Tommy Kabu Movement of the Purari Delta. Oceana 29(2):75-90.\n\n1960. Social Structure and Cultural Change in Papua. American Anthropologist 62:593-602.\n\n1961a. Varieties of Change in Koriki Culture. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology 17:26-39.\n\n1961b. New Men of Papua. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press.\n\n1967. From Cannibal Raid to Copra Kompani: Changing Patterns of Koriki Politics. Ethnology 6(1):309-331.\n\n1973. Archaelogical Investigations in Central Ifugao. Asian Perspectives 16(1):39-70.\n\n1974. Koriki Chieftainship: Hereditary Status and Mana in Papua. Ethnology 13(3):239-246.\n\n1975. The Great Ifugao War: A Study in Archaelogy and Oral History. Asian Perspectives 18(1):64-74.\n\n1978. Ifugao.  -- In --  Studies in Philippines Prehistory. F. Landa Jocano, ed. Pp. 270-305. Quezon City: Institute for Advanced Study, University of the Philippines.\n\n1981. Archaelogical Investigations in the Burnay District of Southeastern Ifugao, Philippines. Asian Perspectives 24(2):223-236.\n\n1984a. Kiyyangan Village of Ifugao Province, Philippines. Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society 12(2):116-127.\n\n1984b. The Purari River Delta Societies, Papua New Guinea, after the Tom Kabu Movement. Ethnology 23(3):217-227."}],"culture":[{"label":"Culture","indexedContent":"Purari (Papua New Guinea people)","content":"Purari (Papua New Guinea people)"},{"label":"Culture","indexedContent":"Namau","content":"Namau"},{"label":"Culture","indexedContent":"Ifugao (Philippine people)","content":"Ifugao (Philippine people)"}],"userestrict":[{"label":"Rights","content":"Contact repository for terms of use."}],"name":[{"flag":["personal_name","personal_main"],"label":"Creator","indexedContent":"Maher, Robert F. (Robert Francis)","content":"Maher, Robert F. {"id":"ebl-1538052636132-1538052636151-0","version":"","unitCode":"NAA","linkedId":"","type":"ead_collection","content":{"id":"sova.naa.ms4252","guid":"https://n2t.net/ark:/65665/nw3448874fe-7317-40c1-8214-f7354245d292","type":"ead_collection","boost":"6","level":"collection","title":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn","freetext":{"odd":[{"label":"Local Numbers","content":"NAA MS 4252"},{"label":"Publication Note","content":"Many of the Sun Dance images are published with explanations in:\n\nScott, Hugh L. \"Notes on the Kado, or Sun Dance of the Kiowa,\" American Anthropologist 13, no. 3 (1911): 345-79."},{"label":"Exhibition Note","content":"Several of the Saynday images are published with associated stories in Saynday Was Coming Along...Silverhorn\u0027s Drawings of the Kiowa Trickster, Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service, Candace Greene and Frederick Reuss, 1993."}],"name":[{"flag":["personal_name","personal_main"],"label":"Creator","content":"Silver Horn, 1860-1940","indexedContent":"Silver Horn"}],"place":[{"label":"Place","content":"North America","indexedContent":"North America"}],"creator":[{"label":"Creator","content":"Silver Horn, 1860-1940"}],"culture":[{"label":"Culture","content":"Kiowa","indexedContent":"Kiowa"}],"setName":[{"label":"See more items in","content":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn","indexedContent":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn"}],"bioghist":[{"label":"Biographical Note","content":"Silver Horn, known as Haungooah in Kiowa, was born in 1860. His name also appears as Hugone, Hangun or Hawgon. He was a member of a prominent Kiowa family. His residential band, led by his father Agiati (Gathering Feathers), actively opposed the United States government\u0027s efforts to confine the Kiowa to a reservation. Members of his family participated in the Red River War of 1874-1875 and were among the last Kiowa to surrender to the military. In 1891, Silver Horn enlisted in Troop L of the Seventh U.S. Cavalry. He served with Troop L, which was part of a  broader experiment involving the enlistment of all-Indian troops, until 1894.\n\nIn 1901, Silver Horn secured employment with James Mooney, an ethnologist with the Bureau of American Ethnology. Mooney was interested in the designs on Kiowa shields and tipis and hired Silver Horn to produce illustrations of the designs and models of the shields and tipis. The project provided Silver Horn with steady work between 1902 and 1904 and occassional employment between 1904 and 1906. Silver Horn also produced illustrations for Hugh Scott, an army officer and avocational ethnologist. Silver Horn was active in the religious life of the Kiowa. He was a Tsaidetalyi bundle keeper and participated in the Sun Dance, Ghost Dance, and Peyote religion. He was also a member of the Ohoma society. Silver Horn died on December 14, 1940."},{"label":"Biographical Note","content":"Hugh Scott was a graduate of the United States Military Academy and served as an officer in the Seventh Cavalry. He was initially stationed in the Dakota Territory. There he learned Plains Indian sign language, a skill that enabled him to communicate more easily with the Cheyenne, Sioux, Crow, and Arikara scouts with whom he worked. He was transferred to Fort Sill, Indian Territory in 1889. From 1891 to 1893, he commanded Troop L of the Seventh Cavalry, an all-Indian troop that was comprised primarily of Kiowa men. He was an avocational ethnologist and compiled a small collection of Plains Indian material during his service in the West, including paintings and drawings by Silver Horn. In 1911, he published illustrations from this collection in \"Notes on the Kado, or Sun Dance of the Kiowa\", which appeared in American Anthropologist."}],"physdesc":[{"label":"Extent","content":"1 Volume (graphite, colored pencil, ink and watercolor on the pages of a bound record book, 8.25 x 13.5 inches)"}],"unitdate":[{"flag":["datechar:creation","normal:1884/1897","type:inclusive"],"label":"Date","content":"circa 1884-1897","indexedContent":"1884/1897"}],"container":[{"label":"Container","content":"Box 1"},{"label":"Container","content":"Box 2"}],"custodhist":[{"label":"Custodial History","content":"Hugh Scott purchased the book from Silver Horn for twenty dollars in 1897. Scott mentions the acquisition of the book in NAA MS 2932. In 1936, Scott\u0027s widow sold the book to the Bureau of American Ethnology for fifty dollars."}],"dataSource":[{"label":"Archival Repository","content":"National Anthropological Archives","indexedContent":"National Anthropological Archives"}],"identifier":[{"label":"Identifier","content":"NAA.MS4252"}],"objectType":[{"label":"Type","content":"Collection descriptions","indexedContent":"Collection descriptions"},{"label":"Type","content":"Archival materials","indexedContent":"Archival materials"},{"label":"Type","content":"Volumes","indexedContent":"Volumes"},{"label":"Type","content":"Works of art","indexedContent":"Works of art"},{"label":"Type","content":"Ledger drawings","indexedContent":"Ledger drawings"},{"label":"Type","content":"Diaries","indexedContent":"Diaries"}],"prefercite":[{"label":"Citation","content":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn, National Anthropological Archives, Smithsonian Institution"}],"processinfo":[{"label":"Processing Information","content":"Information for the collection record was drawn from:\nGreene, Candace S.  Silver Horn Master Illustrator of the Kiowas.  Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2001."}],"altformavail":[{"label":"Existence and Location of Copies","content":"Images of pages with drawings or other content of ethnological interest are available online.  Contact the repository for images of the complete volume.\n\nAccess photocopies of the collection are also available."}],"genre_format":[{"label":"Genre/Form","content":"Works of art","indexedContent":"Works of art"},{"label":"Genre/Form","content":"Ledger drawings","indexedContent":"Ledger drawings"},{"label":"Genre/Form","content":"Diaries","indexedContent":"Diaries"}],"scopecontent":[{"label":"Scope and Contents","content":"The collection consists of a bound volume of preprinted US Army forms for recording results of target practice, subsequently filled with drawings of courting, hunting, warfare, Saynday stories, and scenes from the Kiowa Sun Dance by Silver Horn and other Kiowa artists.  The artists were probably all Army scouts. The book also contains a 30 page pictorial diary by Silver Horn, spanning the period between January 1893 to June 1897. The diary starts near the end of the book and proceeds from the back towards the front. Among the many names inscribed in the book are \"Hawgone\" (Silver Horn) and \"Auchchiah,\" both of whom served in Troop L of the Seventh Cavalry, an all-Indian troop that was commanded by Scott. The manuscript contains 186 drawings, as well as a number of scribbled images. The pages are hand numbered, 5-356, in red ink in the upper left corner of each page. A second hand pagination in black ink runs from the back of the book toward the front, encompassing the last thirty pages of the book. Previous inscriptions in the book record the results of target practice at Fort Meade, Dakota Territory in 1884. Hugh Scott was stationed at Fort Meade between 1883 to 1886.\n\nPlease note that the contents of the collection and the language and terminology used reflect the context and culture of the time of its creation. As an historical document, its contents may be at odds with contemporary views and terminology and considered offensive today. The information within this collection does not reflect the views of the Smithsonian Institution or National Anthropological Archives, but is available in its original form to facilitate research."}]},"language":["eng"],"record_id":"NAA.MS4252","containedIn":[{"url":"https://sova.si.edu/record/NAA.MS4252","type":"Collection","unitid":"Collection NAA.MS4252","unittitle":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn"}],"record_link":"https://n2t.net/ark:/65665/nw3448874fe-7317-40c1-8214-f7354245d292","filelocation":"https://sirismm.si.edu/EADs/NAA.MS4252-ead.xml","collection_id":"NAA.MS4252","fileSignature":"26684d21a11467e2765c9e9f274c0ddf7da25270","metadata_usage":{"access":"CC0"},"archival_repository":"NAA","digital_assets_available":false},"url":"ead_collection:sova-naa-ms4252","hash":"00391687bfb6471382c1e48ad39449f0488721c8","docSignature":"0d79a28668ff7f49853e4c1ec6cef407","timestamp":1661557201,"lastTimeUpdated":1672997701,"title":"MS 4252 Military target record book containing drawings by Silver Horn and others and a pictorial diary by Silver Horn"}
